Description: Body sherd of Chian, possibly Wild Goat Style, pottery plate with carination; yellowish-white slip; interior: painted decoration consisting of bird to right (only legs and part of cross-hatched body remaining); around, broken maeander pattern between two bands of dots; trace of black on rim (mostly lost); exterior reserved with two pairs of dilute lines; part of ancient repair hole at edge of sherd.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The carination at the outside edge of the sherd suggests the existence of a flat ledge rim. Birds are found in Wild Goat Style Chian vases, but are rare on vases of the early 6th century BC. Birds reappear in circa 560BC on black figure cups.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2137) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
